questions.stem: Equine sarcoids are BEST described as:

options.label: A
options.text: Benign melanocytic tumors confined to gray horses

options.label: B
options.text: Locally invasive fibroblastic skin neoplasms associated with bovine papillomavirus (BPV)

options.label: C
options.text: Systemic lymphoid neoplasms affecting multiple organs

options.label: D
options.text: Viral papillomas that always regress spontaneously

questions.explanation: Equine sarcoids are locally invasive fibroblastic skin neoplasms strongly associated with BPV infection. They are not melanocytic tumors (A), systemic lymphoid cancers (C), or viral papillomas that always regress (D).

questions.stem: Equine melanomas are typically:

options.label: A
options.text: Non-pigmented epithelial tumors of the hoof

options.label: B
options.text: Dark-pigmented tumors arising from melanocytes that may be benign or malignant

options.label: C
options.text: Primarily bone tumors of the skull

options.label: D
options.text: Exclusively inflammatory lesions without neoplastic cells

questions.explanation: Equine melanomas are dark-pigmented tumors originating from melanocytes that may behave in a benign or malignant fashion. They are not hoof epithelial tumors (A), bone tumors (C), or purely inflammatory lesions (D).

questions.stem: Which statement about sarcoids is MOST accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: They frequently metastasize to distant organs

options.label: B
options.text: They are locally destructive and invasive but do not typically metastasize

options.label: C
options.text: They are caused by a fungal infection

options.label: D
options.text: They resolve rapidly after minor trauma

questions.explanation: Sarcoids are locally destructive and invasive but typically do not metastasize to distant organs. They do not commonly metastasize (A), are not fungal (C), and rarely resolve after trauma (often the opposite of D).

questions.stem: What is the most important etiologic factor in the development of equine sarcoids?

options.label: A
options.text: Infection with bovine papillomavirus (BPV) transmitted by biting flies

options.label: B
options.text: Chronic exposure to UV radiation

options.label: C
options.text: Selenium deficiency

options.label: D
options.text: Infection with equine herpesvirus-1

questions.explanation: Infection with BPV, likely transmitted by biting flies or via wounds, is the major etiologic factor in sarcoid development. UV exposure (B), selenium deficiency (C), and EHV-1 (D) are not primary causes.

questions.stem: Which horses are MOST commonly affected by sarcoids?

options.label: A
options.text: Older gray horses (>15 years)

options.label: B
options.text: Young horses (average 3–6 years) of any breed, often at sites of previous injury or scarring

options.label: C
options.text: Only foals less than 6 months old

options.label: D
options.text: Only draft breeds with white markings

questions.explanation: Sarcoids commonly affect young horses (around 3–6 years) of any breed, often at sites of previous injury or scarring. They are not restricted to older gray horses (A), foals (C), or specific draft breeds (D).

questions.stem: Which horses are at greatest risk of developing melanomas?

options.label: A
options.text: Young non-gray horses exclusively

options.label: B
options.text: Older gray or white horses such as Lipizzaners, Arabians, and Percherons

options.label: C
options.text: Horses with no pigment on the skin

options.label: D
options.text: Only ponies under 5 years of age

questions.explanation: Melanomas are particularly common in older gray or white horses, including Lipizzaners, Arabians, and Percherons. They are rare in young non-gray horses (A), not limited to depigmented skin (C), and not specific to ponies (D).

questions.stem: Where do melanomas MOST commonly occur in horses?

options.label: A
options.text: Dorsal coronary band and hoof wall

options.label: B
options.text: Perineum, base of tail, and parotid region as black nodules under or within the skin

options.label: C
options.text: Sole of the foot and digital cushion

options.label: D
options.text: Only internal organs with no external signs

questions.explanation: Melanomas usually present as black nodules under or within the skin of the perineum, tail base, and parotid region. Coronary band/hoof wall (A), sole/cushion (C), or exclusively internal lesions (D) are not typical primary sites.

questions.stem: Which of the following is TRUE about the behavior of melanomas in horses?

options.label: A
options.text: They are always benign and never metastasize

options.label: B
options.text: They may remain benign but can transform to malignant forms and metastasize

options.label: C
options.text: They only occur as diffuse skin discoloration

options.label: D
options.text: They always regress spontaneously in gray horses

questions.explanation: Many melanomas may remain benign for years but can undergo malignant transformation and metastasize to internal organs. They are not always benign (A), purely discolorations (C), or guaranteed to regress (D).

questions.stem: Which combination correctly lists systems affected by sarcoids and melanomas?

options.label: A
options.text: Sarcoids: integumentary only; Melanomas: integumentary with possible lymphatic and perineal involvement

options.label: B
options.text: Sarcoids: respiratory; Melanomas: cardiovascular

options.label: C
options.text: Sarcoids: neurologic; Melanomas: musculoskeletal

options.label: D
options.text: Both are primarily gastrointestinal diseases

questions.explanation: Sarcoids mainly affect the integumentary system, while melanomas also involve integumentary structures and may extend to lymphatic, digestive, and perineal regions when large or metastatic. The other options misidentify organ systems (B–D).

questions.stem: Which historical finding is commonly reported by owners of horses with sarcoids or melanomas?

options.label: A
options.text: Sudden onset of high fever and respiratory distress

options.label: B
options.text: One or more firm skin masses that gradually enlarge over time

options.label: C
options.text: Acute collapse with no prior signs

options.label: D
options.text: Persistent diarrhea and weight loss only

questions.explanation: Owners frequently report one or more firm skin masses that gradually increase in size. Acute fever/respiratory distress (A), sudden collapse (C), or purely GI signs (D) are not characteristic presentations.

questions.stem: On physical examination, sarcoids may:

options.label: A
options.text: Present as subcutaneous masses near eyelids or canthi that can become red, fleshy, ulcerated, and invasive

options.label: B
options.text: Always be flat, non-palpable macules

options.label: C
options.text: Be limited to mucous membranes only

options.label: D
options.text: Appear only as alopecic patches without mass effect

questions.explanation: Sarcoids often present as subcutaneous masses, including around eyelids or canthi, which can become red, fleshy, ulcerated, and invasive; they can also occur on trunk and limbs in various morphologic forms. They are not always flat or non-palpable (B), limited to mucosa (C), or simply alopecic patches (D).

questions.stem: On physical examination, equine melanomas typically appear as:

options.label: A
options.text: Non-pigmented papules on the dorsal midline

options.label: B
options.text: Dark black nodules under or within the skin, often at the perineum, tail base, and parotid region

options.label: C
options.text: Vesicular lesions along the lips

options.label: D
options.text: Crusted plaques confined to the pastern region

questions.explanation: Equine melanomas are dark black nodules under or within the skin, most commonly at the perineum, tail base, and parotid region, and can form coalescing plaques. Non-pigmented papules (A), lip vesicles (C), or pastern plaques (D) describe other lesions.

questions.stem: Which diagnostic method is considered the gold standard for confirming sarcoids and melanomas?

options.label: A
options.text: Skin scraping with KOH preparation

options.label: B
options.text: Histopathologic examination of biopsy specimens

options.label: C
options.text: Fecal flotation

options.label: D
options.text: Serum antibody ELISA

questions.explanation: Histopathologic examination of biopsy samples is the gold standard for confirming sarcoids and melanomas, differentiating them from other tumors. Skin scraping (A), fecal exams (C), and serology (D) are not definitive for these neoplasms.

questions.stem: What is a potential concern when performing a biopsy of a suspected sarcoid?

options.label: A
options.text: Biopsy always resolves the lesion

options.label: B
options.text: Incomplete or aggressive biopsy may worsen the sarcoid and stimulate rapid regrowth

options.label: C
options.text: Biopsy is contraindicated because sarcoids are contagious to humans

options.label: D
options.text: Biopsy has no diagnostic value

questions.explanation: Incomplete or aggressive biopsy of sarcoids can exacerbate the lesion and stimulate rapid regrowth, so biopsy must be carefully planned. Biopsy does not resolve the lesion (A), is not contraindicated solely for zoonosis (C), and is diagnostically valuable when done properly (D).

questions.stem: Which imaging modality is MOST useful for defining tumor margins and depth of infiltration in equine skin tumors?

options.label: A
options.text: CT only

options.label: B
options.text: Ultrasonography, with CT/MRI reserved for deeper or periocular lesions

options.label: C
options.text: Radiography only

options.label: D
options.text: Endoscopy

questions.explanation: Ultrasonography is useful for assessing tumor margins and depth; CT and MRI provide further detail for deep or periocular lesions. CT alone (A), plain radiography (C), or endoscopy (D) are less informative for superficial skin masses.

questions.stem: Which treatment is commonly used for both sarcoids and melanomas when complete margins can be obtained?

options.label: A
options.text: Oral antibiotics

options.label: B
options.text: Surgical excision

options.label: C
options.text: Topical corticosteroids alone

options.label: D
options.text: Dietary restriction

questions.explanation: Surgical excision is a primary treatment for both sarcoids and melanomas when complete margins are achievable. Antibiotics (A), topical steroids alone (C), and diet changes (D) are insufficient as sole treatments.

questions.stem: Which local therapy is particularly effective for small or superficial sarcoids and melanomas?

options.label: A
options.text: Cryotherapy (freezing)

options.label: B
options.text: Oral antifungals

options.label: C
options.text: Laser ablation of the hoof

options.label: D
options.text: UV light exposure

questions.explanation: Cryotherapy is effective for small or superficial sarcoids and melanomas by freezing and destroying abnormal tissue. Oral antifungals (B), hoof laser therapy (C), and UV exposure (D) are not standard frontline options.

questions.stem: Which immunotherapy is used specifically for equine sarcoids and has about a 70% success rate?

options.label: A
options.text: Interferon-α injections

options.label: B
options.text: BCG (Bacille Calmette-Guérin) injections

options.label: C
options.text: Rabies vaccine

options.label: D
options.text: Tetanus toxoid

questions.explanation: BCG immunotherapy is specifically used in some sarcoids and has reported success around 70%. Interferon (A) and the vaccines listed (C, D) are not standard immunotherapies for sarcoids.

questions.stem: Which statement about medications for these tumors is MOST accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Sarcoids are best treated with systemic antibiotics alone

options.label: B
options.text: Sarcoids can be managed with BCG vaccine and local chemotherapy (e.g., cisplatin), whereas melanomas rely more on surgical excision and cryotherapy

options.label: C
options.text: Melanomas respond best to antifungals and dewormers

options.label: D
options.text: No treatment is available for either tumor type

questions.explanation: Sarcoids respond to local immunotherapy (BCG) and chemotherapy (e.g., cisplatin, 5-FU), while melanomas commonly rely on surgical excision and cryotherapy; radiation may be used in select cases. Systemic antibiotics alone (A), antifungals/dewormers (C), and “no treatment available” (D) are incorrect.

questions.stem: Which possible complication is of particular concern in horses with large melanomas?

options.label: A
options.text: Development of laminitis

options.label: B
options.text: Obstruction of defecation or interference with normal function due to mass effect

options.label: C
options.text: Severe pruritus and self-trauma only

options.label: D
options.text: Transformation into sarcoids

questions.explanation: Large melanomas, especially in perineal regions, may obstruct defecation or interfere with normal function by mass effect. Laminitis (A), pruritus alone (C), and “transformation into sarcoids” (D) are not typical concerns.
